RE Ohio Cc Dear Sara Hayes I needed a clarification regarding the trading season I thought the trading season starts from May to Sep of each year for NOx SIP Call So is the month of May excluded only for Ohio or is it excluded for all the SIP Call states Thanks Rajneesh Salhotra Original Message From Sara Hayes Sent Tuesday July AM To Taylor Michael E Cc FSBLUESTNuunetuunet Subject Ohio Ohio is trying to provide a cushion for their participating units The May allocations are basically extra allowances that companies may use to comply with the NOx program The month of May is not included in the trading season so by giving allowances during that month Ohio would effectively be giving an extra months worth of allowances for free The allowances in May are in addition to EPAs approved NOx budget for the state EPA has expressed extreme dissatisfaction with the approach and Ohio officials expect that it will have to be removed from the plan

FW OhioOriginal Message From Sara Hayes ENRON Sent Tuesday July PM To Salhotra Rajneesh Subject RE Ohio The trading season was originally May to Oct however court delays caused the season to be pushed back to May for all states This change will only take place in the initial trading season Following years will include the month of May Also I will be out of the office from August Army Reserve Training and Joel will be out next week Monsoor will be available to answer questions you may have but the SIP call is not really his area If you have any questions that you can anticipate now you may want to send them this week Thanks Sara On Jul at Salhotra Rajneesh wrote Dear Sara Hayes I needed a clarification regarding the trading season I thought the trading season starts from May to Sep of each year for NOx SIP Call So is the month of May excluded only for Ohio or is it excluded for all the SIP Call states Thanks Rajneesh Salhotra

RE Conversions Cc Jason I am not sure whether you really require the number of tons mmBtu needed to fire a plant What we really need is the cost of coal and gas in terms of MwH so that you can calculate the difference between power quoted in MwH and the fuel For that the conversions will be as follows Coal The price for coal will be quoted in x Ton To convert it to MwH you will have to do the following Assumptions Heat Content BtuLbs Heat Rate BtuKwH Transportation Cost Ton Cost MwH x Gas The price for coal will be quoted in y mmBtu To convert it to MwH you will have to do the following Assumptions Heat Rate BtuKwH Cost MwH y If possible try to put all the assumptions as inputs in the first sheet to allow changes Give me a call if you need any further clarification Trevor I hope the above conversions are in order Rajneesh Salhotra Rajneesh Salhotra Coal and Emissions Trading Enron Global Markets Original Message From Kaniss Jason Sent Tuesday July PM To Salhotra Rajneesh Subject Conversions Raj Do you know how I can convert the following Number of Tons of Coal it takes to fire a plant Number of MMBtus of Gas it takes to fire a plant I need those conversions in order to do the calculations for the Sip Call Unless I am looking at it wrong and I dont need them Jason

Progressive Flow ControlProgressive Flow Control PFC Restrictions on seasonal allowance withdrawal in the OTR NOx market have been put in place through the establishment of PFC This structure allows for unlimited banking of allowances However if the amount of banked allowances in any year exceeds percent of the total regional emissions cap any emission withdrawals in the subsequent period in excess of percent of the cap must be withdrawn on a twoforone basis two allowances must therefore be withdrawn to offset one ton of NOX emitted Implementation of PFC is through a ratio which defines the percentage of each entitys bank available at The ratio equals percent of the next years budget divided by the total bank The ratio is applied evenly to all regardless of whether their bank exceeds percent of their own budget Progressive flow control if triggered has a large impact because it discourages allowance banking due to the possibility that allowances will be derated by percent In addition withdrawals are more costly if they occur at As a result PFC leads to more dramatic NOX price spikes and valleys Rajneesh Salhotra Coal and Emissions Trading Enron Global Markets

Project NOx SIP Call Final Pending List Cc Jason To avoid confusion use the following for demand and supply imbalance and pricing Demandsupply imbalance for each year Demand Sum of posttechnology emissions Supply Sum of allowances For states such as CT GA MO SC and TN use the state budget from the Inputs sheet for the supply number as of now allowance allocation for units is not available Pricing depending upon the above imbalance When demand supply then simply calculate the average of the various price expectations When demand supply then take the average of the prices starting from the highest until the supply is exhausted Also find out the maximum price expectation When demand supply Progressive Flow Control will kick in only if the demand supply for next year To illustrate Demand Supply then reduce the supply by variable in the Inputs tab of the difference between supply and demand that is by The balance of Banked allowances will carry forward to the next year but not at face value The value applicable for next year will be calculated as follows PFC ratio for next year Applicable percentage NOx Budget for next year Banked allowances This implies that of will be available at face value but the balance of will be available at variable in the Inputs sheet of the face value Applicable percentage will be a variable in the Inputs sheet I somehow forgot to get this longpending thing incorporated in the model The emission limit for NonEGUs is lbsmmBtu Implication The target rate for a holding company will not be but an average To illustrate Plant Heat Input Classification ABC NonEGU DEF EGU GHI EGU Target rate Give me a buzz if you need any help clarification Thanks Rajneesh Salhotra Rajneesh Salhotra Coal and Emissions Trading Enron Global Markets

FW BoilCapOriginal Message From Barlow Merrill Sent Thursday August PM To Salhotra Rajneesh Subject BoilCap Rajneesh Here is a copy of the BoilCap and NOx file which I am submitting for review It is as up to data as I can get it Changes Suggested If the Holding Companys background is red I suggest deleting the duplicated line If the Holding Companys background is black read the comment and do or dont do what I suggest If the Holding Companys background is orange then it is listed twice for the same unit but in different percentages and sometimes Operating companies Can decide to combine this into one line or leave it as it is If the Holding Companys background is pink then I attempted to contact the plantcompany directly for information and the email address or phone number is listed in the comment No one has responded of course Changes Made Holding Company Operator Plant Name Current Tech Future Tech Boiler Type Ownership Nameplate NOx Rate Fuels EGU Major Ownership and Sec Inclusion have been updated by what I found in PowerDat and other sources Sec EGU and NonEGU credit allocations were entered as per EPA data given in hardcopy form Some of this was adjusted regard comments for individual spreadsheet entries New Sources If I found a facility that did not have all its ownership represented I added the missing party below the big maroon line as a new entry Only information I was confident entering was added If I fould a new facility either in operation standby or planned due online by I added its data below the maroon line I can stop by to discuss this if you have any questions Thanks Merrill Barlow Analyst Enron Global Markets Smith St Ste h Houston TX

OENRONOUNACNRECIPIENTSCNMSCHOEN CC Salhotra Rajneesh OENRONOUNACNRECIPIENTSCNRSALHOTR Date Wednesday July GMT Subject Attached is a table that includes the information you requested earlier this week Please give us a call if you have any other questions Thanks Sara The following section of this message contains a file attachment prepared for transmission using the Internet MIME message format If you are using Pegasus Mail or any another MIMEcompliant system you should be able to save it or view it from within your mailer If you cannot please ask your system administrator for assistance File information File SIPgrowthfactorsdoc Date Jul Size bytes Type Unknown SIPgrowthfactorsdoc Inline attachment follows From OENRONOUNACNRECIPIENTSCNMSCHOEN To Salhotra Rajneesh OENRONOUNACNRECIPIENTSCNRsalhotr CC Jacobson Lisa OENRONOUNACNRECIPIENTSCNLjacobso Date Wednesday July GMT Subject Rajneesh here is some of the information we promised The first document contains the NOx SIP Call Electricity growth factors the USEPA used to determine states allowance budgets as well as each states compliance supplement pool amount I will send you the other document in a separate email It is the state by state allocation matrix or have you already downloaded this from Joels website My system keeps locking up and is not letting me attach it Very Frustrating In order to help you reconcile the two spreadsheets I need to better understand where the data in PowerDat comes from Do you know Finally we have been searching for some other reports that look at the number and locations of SCR installations EPA did an analysis about three years ago that was widely criticized We know there are some analyses available from ICF for a fee but havent found anything else yet Ill keep you posted Mary Schoen Environmental Strategies Enron Corp phone fax Original Message From Salhotra Rajneesh Sent Monday July AM To Jacobson Lisa Schoen Mary Cc Woods Trevor Subject RE NOx SIP call issues in your enclosed mail Sincerely Rajneesh Salhotra Rajneesh Salhotra Coal and Emissions Trading Enron Global Markets Original Message From Jacobson Lisa Sent Monday July PM To Salhotra Rajneesh Schoen FW NOx SIP call issuesOriginal Message From Salhotra Rajneesh Sent Tuesday July AM To Jacobson Lisa Schoen Mary Cc Woods Trevor Subject RE NOx SIP call issues Dear Lisa and Mary I enclose the file titled Allocations Version received from EEA that mentions the allocations for the various sources The file titled Powerdat to EEA Data is the output from PowerDat This file enlists plants with capacity greater than MW which are either operating or at standby in only those states that are in the EEA file The data from these two files has been merged and is in the file titled EEA and PowerDat And I am trying to reconcile the list of plants from PowerDat data with that from EEA The rows bold and black represent data common to both PowerDat and EEA Other rows bold but not black represent data that may be common but one cannot be certain And the data from row onwards represent EEA data that was not part of the PowerDat output I would appreciate if you can shed some light on the reasons for the apparent differences in the two databases Sincerely Rajneesh Salhotra Rajneesh Salhotra Coal and Emissions Trading Enron Global Markets Original Message From Jacobson Lisa Sent Monday July PM Supply Demand Curve Cc Jason I forgot to mention one step for the captioned subject Whenever you have time in the morning we can discuss the curve and pricing thing Rajneesh Rajneesh Salhotra Coal and Emissions Trading Enron Global Markets

Pending StuffJason Heres a list of things that are pending Convert Lbs to Tons in all the tables and charts Create a demand and supply table for each season with the names of the holding companies with their respective numbers in a backup sheet Put the current season in the Input sheet for calculating the number of seasons available for compliance Extend the current feature regarding announced technologies to take into account the season for an announced SCR so that it will be effected by the SCR Cap per season Fix the LNB SCR tradeoff Include a feature that spaces out the SCRs depending upon the limit of SCRs per holding company per season Pricing Will discuss this either today evening or tomorrow morning SCR Allocation Schedule Will revert to you on how to handle and whether to move backward forward something better Rajneesh Rajneesh Salhotra Coal and Emissions Trading Enron Global Markets
